block.p: Last-Minute Engine Work Before Fire on Concorde Officials said the Concorde that crashed into a hotel near Charles de Gaulle airport outside Paris, setting off a fireball and killing 113 people, had been delayed from taking off by last-minute repairs to the engine that later burst into flames. Investigators said they had not yet linked the repairs to the crash.

Vow to Pursue Mideast Peace Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, pledged to keep at their halting quest for peace despite the dissolution of the Camp David talks.

President Clinton said the key to a peace agreement was more time for internal debate and reflection by the Palestinians and Israelis. The White House said its envoy, Dennis B. Ross, would soon travel to the region to gauge progress in the aftermath of the summit meeting, but officials ruled out new negotiations in the United States anytime soon.

U.N. Recruits Businesses Some 50 multinational companies joined 12 labor associations and watchdog groups in signing a ''global compact'' urged by Secretary General Kofi Annan. He said companies that operate across borders should promote human rights and environmental protection or risk seeing the consensus that favors open trade and investment erode.

Fiji Rebel Leader Arrested George Speight, who toppled Fiji's elected government in a two-month hostage standoff, was arrested by the military. The surprise action came ahead of the announcement of a new cabinet, which Mr. Speight had demanded be stacked with his supporters.

Governors Yield to Putin A group of Russian governors approved President Vladimir V. Putin's proposal to overhaul the federal tax code, a plan that promises to break their control over billions of rubles in tax receipts.
Ruling on Holocaust Claims A federal judge gave final approval to a $1.25 billion accord to settle the claims of Holocaust survivors who had sued a group of Swiss banks.

Bush and Cheney Hit the Campaign Trail Gov. George W. Bush and his new running mate, Dick Cheney, visited the vice-presidential contender's home state, Wyoming, defending Mr. Cheney's conservative voting record and vowing that the ticket would ''renew America's purpose.''

Gore Seeks Jackson's Aid Vice President Al Gore, campaigning in Chicago, urged members of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's organization, the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, to support him and work to defeat the ''old guard'' represented by the Republican ticket. Mr. Jackson was once a bitter rival of Mr. Gore's, but is now a close ally.

Wildfire Threatens Artifacts Archaeologists worked to identify undiscovered Indian sites in Mesa Verde National Park, in Colorado, in advance of a wildfire that had burned 23,000 acres. The scientists fear that both the flames and the firefighters may destroy artifacts before the fire is tamed.
Not Preserving Digital Legacy The Library of Congress is lagging in collecting and archiving digital material like CD-ROM's and electronic publications, a National Academy of Sciences report warned.

SIDS Linked to Heart Disorder Italian researchers offered the first genetic evidence linking sudden infant death syndrome to a rare heart disorder, long-QT syndrome, which they said could account for up to 30 percent of sudden infant deaths. They suggested that many babies could be saved if all newborns were given electrocardiograms. American experts expressed doubts about the benefits of the tests.

Emphysema Surgery Promising A risky operation to remove part of the damaged lungs of emphysema patients appears to improve their ability to breathe, researchers reported. But Medicare and many private insurers will not pay for it without proof that it works better than standard medical care.

Lazio Blankets State With Political Donations Representative Rick A. Lazio has given a total of $72,500 to all 62 Republican county committees in the state. He also sent an additional $4,000 to four Conservative Party county committees. Mr. Lazio was using a traditional strategy of candidates trying to expand quickly beyond their local support bases: sow good will across the state by financing grass-roots party cadres.

Judge Allows Spraying A federal judge cleared the way for the city to continue spraying pesticides to control the spread of the mosquito-borne West Nile virus. A coalition of environmental groups had sought an emergency order to halt the spraying.
Police Had the Wrong Man Prosecutors said they were virtually certain that the police had wrongly arrested Bently Louis Grant in the attack on Tiffany F. Goldberg with a chunk of concrete.
Abortion Ban Struck Down A federal appeals panel struck as unconstitutional New Jersey's ban on so-called partial-birth abortions. The decision mirrored a recent United States Supreme Court ruling.

Turning to Private Managers New York City plans to hand over control of some of its worst-performing public schools to private companies or nonprofit agencies in the fall of 2001, the city's first such effort. Chancellor Harold O. Levy, who outlined the proposal, did not say how many schools would be turned over to private management, but the program is likely to focus on five to seven in its first year.

Ford to Improve Fuel Economy Ford has decided to raise the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over the next five years. The rise would amount to roughly five miles per gallon. The company will not charge extra for the increased fuel-economy.

Ruling Against Napster A federal judge in San Francisco ordered the online music service to stop allowing users to exchange copyrighted music owned by the major music labels. A lawyer for Napster said the ruling could have the effect of shutting down the service.

Amazon.com Posts Loss The largest online retailersaid it had lost $317 million in the second quarter of the year and that it had stanched the massive drain on its cash reserves that raised doubts in the minds of many investors. The company posted sales of $578 million, up 84 percent of over a year earlier. But that was less than analysts had expected.
